texts.es: Agueda de Jesús Pérez P. tiene 53 años de edad. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es  la venta de nacatamales. Hace más de 24 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que ella ofrece a su variedad de clientes sus deliciosos nacatamales. Ella dio inicio por su familia ya que ellos le enseñaron esta actividad, por lo que también el ayudo a obtener más clientes. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora y luchadora y disfruta mucho de su trabajo ya que la mantiene muy entretenida. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de maíz, leña, cal entre otros productos. Su deseo es construir su cocina ya que actualmente no la tiene.
texts.en:
Agueda de Jesús Pérez P. is 53 years old . She sells tamales for a living and has done this for 24 years. She started this business because her family taught her how and has also helped her get more clients. She is a very hardworking woman who enjoys what she does – it keeps her entertained. She is asking for a loan for working capital to buy corn, firewood, lime and other products. She would like to be able to build a kitchen since doesn’t have one right now.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Nuulua

texts.en:
Nuulua F. is a 35-year-old woman living in the town of Letogo. She is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Nuulua owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas to sell. Nuulua has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Nuulua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nuulua successfully repaid a previous loan from SPBD. which was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Nuulua is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST, which will also be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. The loan will be her second loan from SPBD. Nuulua plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Ana es una madre de 24 años, vive con su pareja y padre de sus 2 hijos en su casa propia. Desde su infancia se dedica al cultivo de plátanos, pero desde que formó su familia empezó a sembrar café, el cual vende a una asociación de productores de su región. Aunque el tipo de café que cultiva no tiene un buen precio, lo rentable es que produce cada 4 meses y una vez iniciada la cosecha, cada 15 días recolecta y lleva su carga a su comprador, por lo que Ana no pierde mucho tiempo, ni gasta en pasajes para comercializar su producto en algún mercado. Por esta razón es que le gusta sembrar este tipo de café, ya que no requiere de mucho trabajo. Asimismo, cuando tiene tiempo libre trabaja, conjuntamente con su esposo, como jornaleros en las chacras de sus vecinos. 
Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP, en los ciclos pasados pagó todas sus cuotas a tiempo y para este crédito renueva su compromiso de cancelar en el día señalado. El dinero que viene solicitando es para la compra de 2000 plantitas de café, ya que tiene anhelos de incrementar su producción.
texts.en:
Ana is 24 year old mother who lives with her partner, the father of her two children. They live in their own home. Ana has grown plantains since she was a small child, but since she started her family she has begun to cultivate coffee that she sells to a local producers’ association. Although the type of coffee she cultivates doesn’t get a good price, it’s profitable because it produces every four months. Once the harvest has begun, she picks it and takes her load to her buyer every two weeks. Ana likes planting this type of coffee since it doesn’t require a lot of work since she doesn’t lose much time, or waste money on traveling to sell her product in a market. When she does have free time, she works with her husband as a day laborer on neighboring plots of land. This is her third loan with MFP. She has paid all of her past loans back on time and promises to pay this new loan off by the due date. The loan she is asking for is to buy 2,000 coffee bushes because she would like to increase her production.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de plantas de café

loans.name: Anibal

texts.es:
Aníbal tiene 36 años, es padre de un hijo y vive con su pareja en una casa alquilada. Hace 16 años se dedica al cultivo de café, paltas y plátanos. Últimamente está cosechando los plátanos cada 15 días y vendiéndolos en su misma chacra por arrobas (12 kilos), mientras espera la cosecha de sus cafetales por un lapso 9 a 12 meses. Una vez iniciada la recolección de este grano (café), junto a su esposa preparan la carga que transportarán hasta el mercado convencional de su provincia, a 45 minutos en carro desde su zona. Por ello, trata de que en un viaje lleve de 8 a 10 quintales, para que le permita cubrir el precio del transporte y sus pasajes. Ya de regreso, con las ganancias obtenidas, compran alimentos para su hogar y vestimenta para sus hijos, lo cual lo llena de mucho regocijo.
Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, por lo que se compromete nuevamente a pagar puntualmente todas sus cuotas. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará 600 plantitas de café para su próxima siembra.

loans.use: Compra de plantas de café

loans.name: Cesar

texts.es:
César es un joven soltero de 24 años y actualmente vive en casa de sus padres. Como es el segundo de 7 hermanos, se ha propuesto mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia. Para ello, ha sembrado café y cayhua en las chacras de sus padres, desde entonces está muy comprometido por trabajar en sus cultivos y también exige a todos sus hermanos que cooperen en los trabajos. César se siente muy motivado por el valioso apoyo de sus padres y quiere esforzarse para generar mayores ingresos económicos para la familia. Por tal motivo, hace un año empezó a estudiar agroindustria en un instituto técnico de su ciudad; pero los fines de semana, desde las 5 de la mañana, está trabajando en sus chacras de cachua, puesto que gracias a estos cultivos puede captar el dinero con el que cubre sus pasajes diarios, pues para el café tiene que esperar hasta la cosecha.
Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, tiempo en que ha demostrado trabajar responsablemente con su banco comunal. El dinero que ahora solicita es para comprar funguicidas contra los mosquitos de sus chacras de cayhua, y con otra parte comprará abono.

loans.use: Compra de funguicidas

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
Luis es un joven emprendedor de 23 años, es padre de un niño de 4 años y vive en una casa alquilada. Con las miras de triunfar mediante sus cultivos agrícolas, viene incrementado cada vez más sus siembras de café, cayhua, rocoto y plátanos. Por tal motivo se levanta a las 4 de la mañana para trabajar las cayhuas, para que pueda cosecharlas en tres meses. Mientras que los jueves, es el día de la recolección de plátanos, debido a que el viernes los envía al mercado de frutas de la ciudad de Lima, donde los vende por caja a 10 ú 11 soles, permitiéndole así acumular muy buenas ganancias. A Luis le gustan sus labores agrícolas, por ser la actividad que realizó desde su infancia; aunque últimamente se siente inclinado por el comercio, pues su anhelo es convertirse en un próspero comerciante. 
Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y durante estos periodos ha demostrado ser un excelente presidente de su banco comunal, contando con el aprecio de todos sus compañeros. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará funguicidas para su chacra de cayhuas, asimismo adquirirá javas (cajas de madera) vacías para el transporte de sus plátanos.
texts.en:
Luis is a Young entrepreneur of 24. He is also the father of a four year old son and lives in a rented house. He hopes to succeed in agriculture and regularly increases his crops of coffee, squash, hot peppers, and plantains. This is why he gets up at four in the morning to work his squash fields so he can harvest them in three months time. In the meantime, he collects plantains on Thursdays since he has to send them to the fruit market in Lima. There he sells them for 10 or 11 soles a box which earns him a good income. Luis enjoys his agricultural work because it’s work he has done all his life, although lately he has been leaning toward business. His dream is to be a great vender. This is his third loan with MFP and he has proved himself an excellent president of his communal bank. He is well regarded by his fellow bank members. Luis plans to buy fungicides for his squash fields and wooden boxes to transport his plantains in.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de funguicidas y cajones para sus frutas

loans.name: Anarosa

texts.en:
Anarosa I. is a 27-year-old woman living in the town of Vaimea. She is married and has 3 infant-aged children. To make a living, Anarosa owns and operates a business venture making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fried foods in the local community. Anarosa has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

Anarosa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anarosa successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Anarosa is now requesting a new loan of 1250 WST, which will also be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. The loan will be the third loan taken out by Anarosa from SPBD. Anarosa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make food products to sell

loans.name: Tiesi

texts.en:
Tiesi F. is a 33-year-old woman living in the town of Samatau3.  She is married and has 2 school-aged children.  To make a living, Tiesi owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale.  Tiesi has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 450 WST a month from these activities.

Tiesi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tiesi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 0 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  Tiesi is now requesting a new loan of 2900 WST which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure.  The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Tiesi plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana A. is a 47-year-old woman living in the town of Vaiusu. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Ana owns and operates a business venture in the arts sector operating a handicraft business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling wood handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Ana has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

Ana joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ana successfully repaid a previous loan of 2250 WST from SPBD, which she used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. Ana is now requesting a new loan of 2950 WST, which will also be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. The loan will be the fifth loan Ana has taken out from SPBD. Ana plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders."

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Juana María

texts.es:
La señora Juana María R. desde hace 16 años se ha dedicado a su actividad de venta de frutas y verduras en su establecimiento ubicado en el mercado Ivan Montenegro del departamento de Managua.

Ha decidido solicitar un crédito para invertirlo directamente en la compra de los perecederos como son frutas y verduras y de esta manera mejorar su situación ya que aumentarán sus ventas de frutas y verduras.

loans.use: Compra de frutas y verduras

loans.name: Toafa

texts.en:
Toafa S. is a 37-year-old woman living in the town of Sinamoga.  She is married and has 4 school-aged children.  To make a living, Toafa owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling baked goods in the local community.  Toafa has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 350 WST a month from these activities.

In 2007, Toafa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Toafa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1750 WST from SPBD.  This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Toafa is now requesting a new loan of 2500 WST which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  The loan will be the 4th loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Toafa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand the borrower's business.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders."

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lidia Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Lidia C. se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas las que son comercializadas por ella misma en su establecimiento en el mercado Ivan Montenegro donde a diario ofrece las tortillas de maíz siendo preparadas por ella misma. 

La razón por la cuál ha solicitado el crédito en Ceprodel es para invertirlo en la compra del maíz y de la leña para continuar elaborando las tortillas y así llevar el sustento a su casa de habitación.

loans.use: Compra de maíz y leña

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
Mr. Choeun T., 64, and his wife, Mrs. Kim Oem, 54, were married in 1969 and have one son who works in the Department of Social Affairs. They live on an island in Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Choeun has been a wooden house constructor for 2 years, a skill he learned from his brother. For work, he travels to other provinces far away from his house. His wife has been selling groceries since 1980. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market, for resale in her village. Choeun is applying for a loan of $1,200 to purchase more grocery items for his wife to sell, and to buy construction cranes for his wooden house construction business.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for his wife to sell, and to buy construction cranes for his wooden house construction business.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Mrs. Horn Pich, age 33, and her husband, Mr. Sokhoeun Vann, age 37, were married in 1993. They have six daughters and one son. Three of the children are in school and one daughter assists her mother in the business. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Pich has been selling vegetables for more than four years. Her husband is a farmer and, besides that, he is a wooden-house builder as well. Pich is asking for a loan of $250 to provide capital for her husband’s farming business.

loans.use: To provide capital for her husband’s farming business

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Mrs. Eng L., age 39, and her husband, Mr. Vanna Doung, age 34, were married in 1995. They have two sons and two daughters. Three of the children are in school and another one is still young. The family lives along National Road Number Six about ten kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Eng has been selling meat and vegetables for about six years. Her husband has been operating a water utility service in his village for more than five years. Eng hopes to expand her business so that she will be able to generate more income for supporting her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna C., 48, and her husband, Mr. Peam Thou, 49, have been married since 1980 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. On of them was married and lives in separated home, one daughter is a silk weaver and other three assist their parents in the business. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 
Vanna is a silk weaver and assists her husband in producing Khmer noodle business. She wants to supplement another raising pigs business and after they grow big enough, she will get more extra income from the selling pigs. 
Therefore, Vanna is asking for a loan of 1,000 UDS to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.use: To use for raising pigs.

loans.name: Duk

texts.en: Duk S., 38, is a domestic nurse. She owns a small pharmacy where she takes care of the patients and sells a various medicine. She is also hired by neighbor to examine them at their house. Almost of her patients are people who live near her clinic. Duk S. is a married mother blessed with two school-aged kids who are dependent on her income, while her husband, Um Chanravy, age 37, who is shown in the picture here. He is a military policeman. Duk S. is taking out her fist loan to purchase more medicines for her medical clinic.

loans.use: to purchase more medicines for her medical clinic

loans.name: Sam-Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Sam-un S., 31, and her husband, Mr. Vannak Seng, 29, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2003 and have one daughter and one young son.

Sam-un has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She also taught her husband to become a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in a market located in Phnom Penh.

Sam-un is asking for her first loan of 200 USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is 48 years old and lives with her father-in-law and four children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. The middle two daughters attend university while the youngest daughter goes to a local secondary school. During the day, Halima works at a local wool-separating factory in her town. At night, she makes traditional Mongolian shoes by hand. Halima has been making shoes for many years now; she graduated from a college as a shoe maker in 1979 and worked at a shoe factory until it was closed down. Her shoes are well known and valued by her customers for their quality and design. She sells her shoes for 6,000-60,000 tugrugs (~4-42 USD) and receives between 50-60% net profit for each pair. Halima would eventually like to expand her little shoe making shop into a factory employing several people. She is requesting a 770,000 tugrug (~540 USD) loan to purchase materials such as glue, leather, rubber and tools for her shoe making business.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as glue, leather, rubber and tools for her shoe making business.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly M. is 49 years old. Her husband’s name is Ly Smael, age 52, and he is shown in the photo above. To earn a living, this couple owns decorating equipment which they rent it out to people who need to apply make up or decorate for their parties or other ceremonies. The family typically generates a revenue of US$8 each day and have been in their business for seven years.

Currently, Ly M. is running her service very well and has a lot of customers who recognize the good service she provides. She will use her loan to accumulate a larger quantity of her decorating materials in order to better satisfy her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger quantity of her decorating materials

loans.name: Sovantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sovantha C., 26, is a garment factory worker. She has been married Mr. Sithou Horn, 26, a mechanic, for more than three years and has a young son. They live in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh.

The young couple is in the process of renovating their house (tile the floor and plaster a wall), but they lack money to finish it. That’s why Sovantha is applying for her first loan of $700 to finish the work.

loans.use: To finish renovating her house

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mr. Ly H., 47, and his wife, Mrs. Rohimas Meo, 41, live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1993 and have two sons and one daughter. The children all study at a local school.

Ly and his wife have been fishing since they were young. They fish from the Mekong River and sell at the village market. Ly has different kinds of fishing materials, but some are old and he wants to repair them. He will then able to increase the amount of fish he catches. Therefore, Ly is requesting a loan of $500 to repair his fishing materials.

loans.use: To repair fishing materials.

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Sewing clothes is the main part of 52-year-old S. N.'s daily routine. Mrs. S. N. provides her service to her neighbors: sewing both traditional clothes and modern clothes. She runs her business very well and a lot of customers recognize the good service she provides.

S. N. is married to Samet, 51, a fish seller, and they have seven children. Two of their daughters are employed in a garment factory. S. N. will use half of her loan to buy more tailoring tools and the rest to accrue capital for her husband's fish selling business.

Note: the photo is of Mrs. S. N.'s husband.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring tools and for her husband's fish selling business

loans.name: Channy

texts.en: Mrs. Channy M., 39, has been selling boiled corn for a year. She and her husband, Mr. Srun Sun, 41, were married in 1985 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Channy’s children commute to school a far ways from home. They have to spend a lot of money for traveling costs which is expensive for the family. Hence, Channy is applying for her first loan of US $800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school. Her eldest son has a full-time job, one child is a musician and the other two attend school. Channy's husband has been a sewing machine repairman for 10 years. They live in a small village off of National Road No. 2 about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school

loans.name: Sa

texts.en: Sa M., age 49, is a local cloth vender. She sells in retail a piece of cloth to passer-by from the village to village around her community. almost of her buyers who need her cloth to apply for their uniform and their other decorating tool. She also gets a profit of approximately of $3 per day from her investment and provides her income to contribute her family’s daily foods. Her husband assists her in selling cloth. Sa M. is applying for a loan to increase her successful business capital. Sa M. has four children: two are married and two are students and also helps selling her product when they are not studying. Note: Sa M. was not available at that time so her husband is shown instead of the picture.

loans.use: To increase her successful business capital

loans.name: Ma. Susan

texts.en: Ma. Susan owns and manages a general store business. She is 47 years old, married and the mother of three children.  She and her husband are striving hard in their businesses to provide for their daily needs. Ma. Susan rents a stall in her village where she displays different commodities like bread, vegetables, fruits, frozen foods, fish, chicken and other grocery items. She hopes to maintain her business with the help of lenders, so she is now asking to borrow 18,000 pesos. This loan will be a great help in maintaining and improving the business she has started and will be used to purchase more goods. She hopes that her family will always be healthy so they can reach their dreams.

loans.use: For the maintenance and development of her retail business

loans.name: Dinaliza Ana

texts.en:
Dinaliza Ana G. is from the village of Romarate, Aurora, Zamboanga del sur. She is 40 years old. Dinaliza Ana is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dinaliza Ana owns & operates a "sari-sari" retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Dinaliza Ana has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns about 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Dinaliza Ana joined GDMPC in order to gain access to financial services to help improve her standard of living and be able to engage in business activities. Dinaliza Ana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Dinaliza Ana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Dinaliza Ana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher people, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria O. is from the village of Villalin, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Victoria is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Victoria owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising and selling pigs. Victoria has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns about 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Victoria joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services in order to help improve her standard of living and be able to engage in business activities. Victoria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from GDMPC, which was used to purchase livestock, feed, and other supplies. Victoria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more livestock, feed, and other supplies. This loan will be the third one taken out by Victoria from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisher people, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock, feed, and other supplies.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en: Yolanda is a retailer of personal and home products from Fuller Life.  Some of her products includes Medicines, House cleaner, disinfectant, powdered soap and other things that needed at home.  She would like to avail a loan of PHP10,000 as additional capital for her business. She believes that through the loan her business will become more profitable by having more products.  She hopes that she will be given the chance to further expand her business with the lenders help.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business to purchase more stocks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Neriza

texts.en:
Neriza F. is from the village of Cabungaan Clarin in Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old and is married with 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Neriza owns & operates a business venture, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting banana for sale. Neriza has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Neriza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Neriza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Neriza is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Neriza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to pay the tuition fees of her children and save for any future emergencies. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en:
Rosana is 41 years old  and married to Andres. They are thankful for they were blessed with four children, one of whom is is already married.  They live in the village of Sta. Rosa, Santiago City. 

Rosana manages a store while also selling fish and baked breads in their village twice a week.  She would like to take a loan of PHP5,000 for use as additional capital in her vending business. This amount will really help her to make her business grow by having more goods to sell.

Rosana budgets her income for her childrens school allowance, projects and tuition fees. She hopes that she will be able to continue sending her children to school until college.

loans.use: Additional capital for the growth of her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bot

texts.en:
Mr. Bot N., 39, and his wife, Mrs. Rio Chhorn, 34, have been married for 10 years. They have one daughter, who attends school. They live in a small village off of National Road number Two, which is about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Bot has been driving a Tuk Tuk taxi for 3 years. His wife has been selling fruits for 10 years. Unfortunately,his Tuk Tuk taxi is broken in some parts, which upsets his business. So he is applying for a loan of US$500 to purchase new Tuk Tuk taxi to replace his old one.

loans.use: To purchase a new taxi to replace his old one.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 46 years old.  Her husband works in a trucking company in Metro Manila.  They have five children: Mary Jane- 21 years old, college graduate;Salathiel Jr.- 19 years old, computer technician;Sarah Jane- 15 years old, 4th year high school student; Mary Grace- 13 years old, 2nd year high school student and Jay Mark- 9 years old, grade 3.  Their house is located at Sillawit, Cauayan City.

She is a dressmaker for how many years.  Her sewing business is located inside her house and she can earn a daily income of PHP200.00. She now wanted to avail a loan of PHP5,000.00 to purchase some needles and thread to use in her sewing business and to have an additional capital for the continuous stability of her small business.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sewing business

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy P. is from the village of Malibangcao Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old and married with 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a specialized maize retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling corn in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Daisy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Daisy from GDMPC and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her maize sales business

loans.name: Meu

texts.en: Meu F. is a 59 year old widowed mother caring for five children. All five children are still living in the family home and are employed in different jobs. Meu F. is a recycling seller - she buys used goods to sell to a wholesaler, who then sells the goods in bulk to other countries. The used goods she deals in is mostly leftover electricity wires. Meu F. is looking for a loan to use as capital to buy more stock to increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy more used goods to resell

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
Loreta is 48 years old. She and her husband Carlos have three children and are thankful for their harmonious relationship. Loreta runs a fruit vending business, selling bananas while her husband is busy in their rice fields. She believes that patience and humility are necessary in fulfilling life dreams.

Loreta hopes to fulfill her dreams by working hard in her business and improving sales activity through financial assistance from lenders amounting to PHP5,0000.

loans.use: Improvement to her fruit vending business

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora owns and operates a business venture in front of their house. She has a general store in which she sells different commodities. Aside from grocery items, she also sells various vegetables and fruits for additional income. Aurora has been managing her business for 10 years and she always aims to improve it further to be able to maintain their way of living and to continuously share her blessings with her children. With this, she is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP 22,000 from the lenders.  This will be used to purchase more grocery items in order for her store to become profitable.

Aurora is now 49 years old, married and blessed with three children.  They are living in the village of San Juan, Quirino, Isabela.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her store.

loans.name: Chrech

texts.en:
Mrs. Chrech C., 44, and her husband, Mr. Keo Um, 43, have been married since 1984 and have 5 children: 3 sons and 2 daughters. Four of them have full-time employments and another one attends school. They are living in a small village off of National Road number Two about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chrech and her husband sell fruits in Phnom Penh. The couple wants to expand their business, they will able to earn much income as well. So, Chrech is applying for a loan of US$100 to purchase additional fruits for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits for resale.

loans.name: Cleofe

texts.en:
Cleofe is 28 years old and married to Antonio, a farmer.  They live in the village of Addalam Jones, Isabela. Their marriage was blessed with two children: Aron Kate, six years old, and Janel, three years old. The couple works hard for the future of their children. 

Cleofe is a vegetable vendor while her husband is busy cultivating their rice farm, which is their main source of income. She would like to maintain her vegetable farm business so that she has more vegetables to sell. For this, she is requesting a loan from the KIVA lenders amounting to PHP 4,000. She hopes that business will improve because her family relies on her business income for their daily needs. Cleofe and Antonio said, “that through cooperation of the family members and good relationship of each other they will be able to attain victorious in life”.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Moa

texts.en: Moa P., 52, is a low-income people currently living in Phnom Penh. To earn a living, she sells some cooking supplies to the neighbors from her home and is typically earning an average of $3 a day to be supportable for her family. Moa P. is married to Beung Ponh, age 57, a land trader. He also helps his neighbor to buy a plot of loan for a commission. This older couple now lives with three single children; one of whom works in construction and others are attending school. Moa P. will use her loan to buy more grocery items and to buy rice in bulk which she will sell it out when the commanding high price.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items and to buy rice in bulk which she will sell it out when it is commanding high price

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.en:
Esmeralda C. is from the village of Camanga, Tukuran, Zamboanga del sur. She is 28 years old. Esmeralda is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Esmeralda owns & operates a specialized vegetable retail store, selling vegetables in the local community. Esmeralda has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Esmeralda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esmeralda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Esmeralda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Esmeralda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional vegetables to sell

loans.name: Mas

texts.en: Mas T. is 34 years old and has been selling a few fresh fish in the local busy market for more than seven years. She sells fish that she buys them from her wholesale supplier or from the river which is full of fishermen. She married, but divorced her husband since her two children were very young. In the past, Mas T. needs to pay the cost of hiring taxi for transporting her fish to sell at the market. She right now hopes to have a motor for supporting her business, but she doesn’t have money to buy it. Therefore, she would like a loan on Kiva in order to buy a used motorcycle for transporting purposes.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle for transporting purposes

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine E. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del sur. She is 40 years old. Josephine is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a specialized fishing retail store, selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and pay the tuition of her children.. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Bolortuya

texts.en: Bolortuya is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Dornogobi province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her son, age 8, attends a local secondary school while her daughter, age 5, attends kindergarten. Her youngest child is an 8-month-old infant who stays at home. Bolortuya owns and operates a local public bath house. These bath houses are important for local people, as many of them do not have running water with which to bathe. She began her business in 2007 and she earns between 150,000 and 200,000 tugrugs per month. While her business is doing well, it can be expensive to maintain a public bath house. Bolortuya replaced one third of her showers last year, and these repairs make it hard to expand or significantly improve her business. Because of this, she is requesting a 900,000 tugrug loan in order to make repairs and remodel her bath house.

loans.use: To make repairs and remodel her bath house.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is managing a store in the village of Angoluan Echague. She is married to Alfredo and they have three children: Albert-20 years old college graduate; Gener-18 years old and Alexander-14 years old who is a high school student. Melinda wishes that her children will all finish their studies.  This is thre reason why they keep on working hard for them to provide their educational needs.  

“Through sacrifices and patience you can achieve success” said Melinda. Her family have cooperation to each other. Melinda would like to buy additional merchandise to be further minimize her fare in going to and from the market. But her capital is insufficient that’s the reason why she is asking additional financial support to the KIVA lenders to be able to generate bigger income for her family needs. She is requesting a loan amounting PHP5000 for her business expansion and improvement.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Jonaldine

texts.en:
Jonaldine B. is from the village of Palilan, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 30 years old. Jonaldine is single. Jonaldine owns & operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fish. Jonaldine has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2007, Jonaldine joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonaldine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell.

Jonaldine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jonaldine from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn V. is 24 years old and married to Marlon V.. The couple is blessed with two children: Jessica Jane, 2 years old, and Jessabel, 4 months old. Rubelyn is a tricycle operator and a fish vendor, and is also engaged in the business of buying and selling recyclable materials.

She hopes to improve her family's standard of living. Rebelyn believes that through “sacrifices and patience” they will be able to achieve success in life. Rubelyn and Marlon are helping one another provide for the needs of their family. Rubelyn would like to have additional capital for the maintenance of her tricycle and for her other businesses, selling fish and dealing in recycled materials. She hopes to get a loan from the Kiva lenders in the amount of PHP5000.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of her tricycle.

loans.name: Nabihan

texts.en: Navihan is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two children, a daughter aged 23 and a son aged 18, in a house in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. His wife is unable to work because of a serious illness she contracted while working at a local mining company. Navihan, along with his daughter, operates a retail clothing business from a rented stall at the local market. Navihan’s daughter was unable to go to university when she graduated high school because of the high cost of tuition. Navihan began his business in 2004 so that he could provide a better life for his wife and children. Since then, the business profits have enabled him and his family to build a new home. Navihan not only wants to expand his clothing stall into a large clothing shop, but he  also wants to be able to pay for both of his children to go to university so that they can get a good education. Navihan is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~2100 USD) loan to both purchase more clothes so that he can offer more products to his customers, and to help pay for his children’s tuition fees.

loans.use: to help pay for his children’s tuition fees

loans.name: Emely

texts.en:
Vending of vegetables is  the chosen business of Emely. She is married to Rolando Sr and they have four children: Rolando Jr.-20 years old;Richard-19 years old followed by Christopher-12 years old and Jesusa Mina-6 years old. They would like to develop their business through asking additional capital to the KIVA lenders. 

Emely is looking forward for the success of her business. She is thankful because her husband help her in their vegetable planting and selling business. She would like to borrow additional capital amounting PHP4000. She would be glad if this loan amount will be granted for this will helps her to purchase more seedlings and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase farm inputs

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Hun-Eng

texts.en:
Mrs. Hun-eng S., 41, and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Seng, 42, live in a small village off of National Road number 2 about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. They were married in 1987 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Three of them are attending school, one of whom is studying at university level. 

Hun-eng is a primary teacher. Her husband has been growing rice since he was young. One of Hun-eng’s sons is a guide, so she is applying for her first loan of $800 to add to her own money to purchase a van for her son, which will be used in his business as transportation for his customers.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a van for her son.

loans.name: Jamish

texts.en:
Jamish is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of her three children attend a local secondary school. Her husband operates a taxi service in their town, and Jamish has a rented stall at a local market from which she sells clothing.

Her husband started his business in 2003 and after his business became successful, Jamish managed to start her clothing business in 2006. Their stable businesses enabled them to upgrade their car this year. Her husband's taxi service business earns around $1.40 to $3.50 a day. Jamish is planning to expand her stall into a little shop and to trade in their car for a Japanese make. For that reason she is working hard every single day. She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more clothing for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma, is 59 years old.  She is married to Bernardo Sr. and they were blessed with five children: John, is now working in South Korea;Flora, Vilma, Gema and their youngest is Bernardo Jr.- 16 years old, a high school graduate.  Four of them are already married.  They are residing in Sillawit, Cauayan City, Isabela.  

She mananas a typical village store for almost two years and she can earn a gross income of PHP1,000.00 a week. She decided to borrow a loan amounting to PHP18,000.00 from the KIVA lenders.  She will use the loan to purchase grocery items and beverages to sell in her retail store. She hopes that lenders will grant her loan for her to gain a prosperous and productive way of living.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase grocery items

loans.name: Sarahan's Group

texts.en:
Sarahan is the leader of this group. She is 46 years old and has raised four children, two daughters and two sons. Her eldest daughter, age 23, works as a nurse in the city hospital. The others are college students. It is quite burdensome to pay for all of the children’s education. However, Sarahan believes in the importance of education and sees it as a valuable investment in future prosperity, so she and her husband are ready to work day and night to give their children a chance to become educated.

Eight years ago, Sarahan’s sister-in-law suggested selling vegetables. Sarahan decided to give it a try. She had enough courage to invest $700 in vegetables to sell. Currently, Sarahan provides for the whole family by selling vegetables and earns $605 which is just ninety-five dollars less than her initial investment.

Her husband helps her bring the vegetables from the market. He also brings vegetables for other people who trade in vegetables. Selling vegetables has allowed them not only to live quite a decent life, but also to save enough money to buy a house. Now Sarahan and her husband need a loan to purchase fruits, and from the gains they are going to pay tuition fees for their children. In the near future they want to open their own container for selling vegetables. Sarahan’s partners are: Ainagul, 49, who has three children. Her two sons work and her smallest daughter is a school student. Her husband is retired, but works part time at a hospital. Ainagul trades in women’s clothes and shoes. She needs a loan to purchase goods. Gulira, 35, is the mother of three children. Her husband is a builder. Gulira is engaged in selling shoes. She used to work as a school teacher until a friend of hers suggested selling socks. That was the start. Gulira needs a loan to purchase goods. Sveta, 44, is a widow. She has four children. Only her eldest son works and lives in the capitol. The others go to college. Sveta trades in clothes. Sveta needs a loan to get one more spot in the market for selling clothes.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- Mol Bulak Finance This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. loans.use: To purchase fruit to sell in order to pay tuition fees for her children.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly M., 45 years old, is married woman and mother. Currently, Ly M. stays at home to be responsible of a daily routine: she cares for the children and cooks delicious meal for family. The family’s current expenses is contributed by her husband’s business, he drives a trailer taxi(tuk tuk). This couple has given birth to six children who are single people. Three of their children are employed: one is a taxi driver and two are garment workers. Ly M. hopes to encourage her unemployed daughter to have an occupation as a grocery seller at the market, but she is not money to operate this activities. Therefore, she has decided to seek a loan of US$200 which enable to her daughter use to begin selling grocery item. Note: Ly M.'s husband appears in the picture over.

loans.use: To begin selling grocery item

loans.name: Rokey

texts.en:
Mrs. Rokey K. and her husband, Mr. Mat Sos, live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have eight children: Two of them were married and live outside the family home, two assist their father in the business, one is autistic person and other three are in school.  

Rokey has been selling chicken and duck for over 2 years. She buys them her villagers and transports to sell in Prek Tamak market about 3 kilometers for her house. Mrs. Mat Sos has been a fisherman since he was young. 
By the way, Rokey needs to spend a lot of money to rents the space of the store for selling chicken and duck. It’s difficult for her to manage income to support her family, so she requesting her first loan of 400 USD to purchase her own store for her business and buy fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a store for her selling chicken business and buy fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.name: Rita's Group

texts.en:
Rita is the leader of this group. Rita has three children and like any mother she thinks about their future. Her eldest son, 24, is single. He provides cargo transportation services for local villagers. Another one of Rita’s sons works as an ironer in a garment factory. Her little daughter, 13, is a school student. Rita has done a lot to give them a good upbringing. Now she works as the head of the local post office.

In addition, Rita keeps some cows and manages to sell twenty to twenty-five liters of milk a day. She discovered her spirit of enterprise back when her parents-in-law gave her a cow and five sheep as a wedding gift. It would have been quite natural to just gradually butcher the sheep for a meat supply and even to sell the cow, as it was some thirty years ago when she was young. However, she kept these animals, and by combining her earnings with her husband’s, they have been able to buy a lorry and furniture. Now, just from selling milk, she earns about $70 a month.

Rita has decided to apply for this loan because she wants to purchase seven sheep for breeding. Her ultimate goal is to increase the total livestock population, so that when her two sons marry, she will be able to help them build homes for themselves. Rita’s partners are: Akak, 33, has two children. Her husband is a hairdresser and she helps her husband earn their family’s living by selling milk. Akak hopes to get a loan to buy a calf. She would spend the rest of the loan for harvesting. Dinara, 43, is divorced. She has raised one son. Dinara has diverse occupations: she teaches the Kyrgyz language at school, keeps a garden, and sells ten liters of milk a day. She needs a loan to buy a cow. Venera, 44, is divorced. She has three children. She has worked as a teacher of Russian language and literature. She also sells milk, which greatly helps her cover most of the family expenses. She needs a loan to buy some sheep. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.
