After finishing the school in spite of entering the university she started her own business because she needed money to be able to support her parents to pay for household and personal expenses. Mehrangez is in this business for 2 years already. For these years she managed to make her business stable and profitable generating the stable incomes for her family, allowing her supporting her parents. Now Mehrangez is planning to expand her business and in order to do so, she’ll need to increase her working capital for purchasing the new clothing for selling. With this purpose Mehrangez requests $800 US Dollars. She promises to repay the loan promptly and thanks all supporting her.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing the new goods for selling in order to expand the business

loans.name: Aibolit

texts.en: Aibolat is 28 years old and lives with his wife and three children in a house in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. His two oldest children go to kindergarten while the youngest one stays at home with her mother. Aibolat operates a taxi service between the countryside and the capital of the province. He started his business in 2004 with a small car. After several successful years in business, Aibolat was able to afford to buy a larger, more reliable automobile. He was also able to build a home for his family with his taxi earnings in 2008. Aibolat began to supplement his taxi service earnings by transporting raw materials such as sheepskins, goat skins and wool from the countryside to the province center. Aibolat works very hard to provide for his family and to pay for his youngest daughter's medical expenses. He says, “My only wish is to support my children’s education and have them become good people”. Aibolat is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase parts for his automobile and some construction materials for his new home.

loans.use: to purchase parts for his automobile and some construction materials for his new home.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 40 years old, married and gifted with three children, and all of them are studying. She believes that “poverty is not the hindrance to success”. This is the reason why she keeps on working hard to send her children to school and provide the needs of her family.

Marilou has been engaged in a furniture-making business for six months. Her husband is a farmer and his income is not enough to provide their basic needs. She wants to improve her business so she is borrowing PHP 5,000 which will help her to purchase the necessary materials needed for making furniture.

loans.use: To buy the materials needed for making furniture

loans.name: Muwanga's Group

texts.en: N. Muwanga is a 42 year old lady and married with 8 children as she takes care of 13 orphans. She is a business lady involved in the sale of refreshments in Najjembe market for 5 years where she sells mostly to the customers in the taxis and cars along Kampala Jinja highway. She employs people who help with running her business although most of the staff are unruly and the on and off power. She is able to make 20,000/= a week as profits and this is due to the good customer care and the good prices of her products. She plans to own a shop for refreshments for increased income as well as educating her children to the last level. She needs a loan to help increase her business capital by buying more business stock and farm inputs since she is also a farmer and needs fertilizers for increased output.

loans.use: Buying more soft drinks for increased stock and farm inputs for quality out put.

loans.name: God's Time Is The Best Group

texts.en:
“God's Time Is the Best” is a group of five borrowers led by Maima H., a 43-year-old married woman. Maima has six children aged 5 to 16 years old with educational levels of 2nd through 7th grade. She also cares for two siblings.

Maima is illiterate due to lack of financial support from her parents. She lives and works in Jatu Town, Banjour, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. This community is a newly-formed residential area; that means it’s not crowded - in fact it’s deserted. Because Banjour is bushy, not many people live there.

Maima's business is food preparation. She buys food like fish, flour, plantain and soft drinks. She fries the food separately and sells it to the residents. She has been running this business for four years and hopes to grow her business into a general goods store.

Maima prepares delicious food to encourage more customers to buy from her. She needs this loan to purchase more food like fish, plantain, flour and soft drinks wholesale to improve her business.

Maima dreams of buying land and building a house for herself and her family.

loans.use: To buy more food and ingredients to grow her business

loans.name: Aidos

texts.en: Aidos is 26 years old and lives with his wife and four year old son in the Bayan-Ulgii province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Aidos operates a retail meat business in his town. He began his business in 2004 and after several years of operation, he has managed to establish himself in the business community. Aidos delivers meat to three local cafes for use in their food preparation. He also has individual customers who buy his meat on a regular basis. In order to expand his business in the past, he has previously received four loans from local banks and has always been reliable in paying these loans back. Because of his business success, he has managed to build a one room house for his family, though he would like to add on to this house in the future as his son gets older. Aidos is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan in order to purchase several cows which he will use for his meat business.

loans.use: to purchase several cows which he will use for his meat business.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
“In everything you do, put God first,” says Aurelia B.. Aurelia is 53 years old, married and lives in the village of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is thankful because she has a responsible husband who is helping her in raising her hogs. Aurelia is married to Juanito, who is also engaged in a rice-farming business. The couple have been blessed with five children, some of whom are already married.  

Aurelia is raising hogs in her village. She would like to buy a supply of feed to further minimize her expenses in going to and from the market, but lack of capital hinders her. For this reason, she is now requesting a loan from the Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 4,000.  This loan amount will be a big help most especially in sustaining the needs of her family. She hopes her request for a loan is granted.

loans.use: To buy feed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: God Bless The World Group

texts.en:
“God Bless The World” is a group of five borrowers led by John T., a 35-year-old married man. John has three children aged 5 to 9 years old with educational levels of 2nd through 3rd grade. He also cares for a sibling.

John is illiterate due to poverty. He lives and works on the Hotel Africa Road, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. This community is full with people that were displaced by the civil crisis. The government provided shelters in this community for them.

John's business is a general goods store. He buys general goods like slippers, bath soap, foodstuffs, etc., wholesale and sells to the residents of Hotel Africa Road. He has been running this business for two years and is hoping to grow his business to a bigger general goods store.

John sells quality products and has a good approach to customers to encourage more customers to buy from him. He needs this loan to purchase more goods wholesale to improve his business.

John dreams of buying land and building a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for his store

loans.name: Asilbek

texts.en: S. Asilbek is 33 years old and lives with her mother, husband and two children in Bayan-Ulgii province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, and her two young sons both attend kindergarten. Asilbek manages a pharmacy with the help of her husband in her town. She is a doctor therefore sells a variety of medicines, and treats people in their shop. Due to it's location in a high traffic area near the local market, the pharmacy attracts many customers. Asilbek started her current business in 2005 after previously managing a medicine trading center in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She then moved to Bayan-Ulgii and started a medicine transportation service between Russia and her province. Over the years, Asilbek has gained much business experience and built a positive reputation for her buisiness in the community. She says, "My future dream is to expand my pharmacy in order to increase my sales." She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (~1750 USD) loan to purchase more medicine for his pharmacy.

loans.use: to purchase more medicine for his pharmacy

loans.name: Battsetseg

texts.en: Battsetseg is 50 years old and lives with her husband in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. She and her husband live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Battsetseg and her husband operate a grocery store in their town. They began their business in 2000, and since then, they have been able to buy their own store which enables them to sell larger quantities of food. Battsetseg wants to keep expanding the amounts of products her store sells so that her neighbors will not have to go to larger markets farther away in order to buy their groceries. She says, “My wish is to own our own house in the future.” Battsetseg is requesting a 600,000 tugrug (~425 USD) loan in order to purchase a large amount of groceries to sell for the upcoming winter months.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for resale

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 34-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Hussein has owned a mobile phone shop for a year now. He sells mobile phones and accessories, and he also repairs phones. He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase new mobile phones and their accessories. This is the first time that Hussein has requested a loan. 

People from his region know Hussein well because he is known for having a good reputation. His clients are mainly his friends and neighbors. When Hussein first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties since he has a good networking group. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his shop.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones and accessories

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic is married to Rolando, a farmer. She is 44 years old, blessed with four children, three of them are married.  They are living in a peaceful village of Sillawit, five to seven kilometers from the city proper of Cauayan City.

Marivic is engaged in the barbecue vending business for almost one year until she decided to venture into retailing business.  Her weekly net income is PHP1,000.00.  She is now borrowing  a loan of PHP7,000 from the KIVA lenders as additional working capital and for her business expansion. She's been working so hard to support her family and she wants to improve more her business.

loans.use: Additional Capital in her retail store

loans.name: Mouhamad

texts.en:
Mouhamad is a 46 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Mouhamad has owned a coffee shop for a over year now. He offers all sort of coffee and he also serves narguileh (also known as shisha in Egypt). Narguileh is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Narguileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, Europe and other countries. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise and change the décor of his coffee shop. This is the first time that Mouhamad has requested a loan. 
Mouhamad opened his coffee shop at a strategic point which is in the middle of the city, therefore, he is well known and people feel comfortable going to his coffee shop. His clients are mainly his friends and neighbors. When Mohamad first started his business, he passed through some financial issues He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have an independent work since he was unemployed and couldn’t find a work. In the future, he plans on improving his shop.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and change the décor of his coffee shop.

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en:
Ghassan is a 59 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon with his wife and their three children. Ghassan has owned a grocery store for the past eight years. He requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is his third cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loans helped him improve his store by diversifying his merchandise. Ghassan is special in his work because his store is well located; in his neighborhood there is a lot of companies and he also often receives tourists. His clients are mainly his friends, neighbors and passer-bys. When he first started his business, he had to face the competition with another grocery store. Ghassan decided on doing his business because he was unemployed and couldn’t another work. In the future, he plans on improving his store by diversifying more his merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Benida

texts.en:
Benida is 51 years old, married and living in the village of Addalam Jones, Isabela. They have three children and all of them are already working. Benida would like to buy additional merchandise and expand her store in order for her to improve their way of living. Her husband is in full support in her business though her husband is busy managing their rice fields.

Benida is managing a sari-sari store within their village.According to her she would like to expand her store that’s why she is requesting a loan of PHP5,000 that she can use to purchase additional groceries to her store. She is hoping that her loan request will be granted for her business to become profitable for the welfare of her family.

loans.use: Additional capital for the business improvement

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Knitted cradle vending is the business of Rosario V. from Barangay Agoluan of Echague, ISabela. She lives there with her husband and three children who are Alejandro - 24 years old, is an elementary graduate;Diana Rose - 21 years old just ended in high school and the youngest is Rogelio V. Jr. - 19 years old. 

Rosario wanted to improve her selling business but she do nott have enough capital to use. In this regard. Rosario realize to seek for financial assistance from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP5, 000 as additional business capital to grow her business. 
 
Rosario and her husband Rogelio V. Sr. strive hard for the fulfillment of her family dreams in life. She hopes that she could be able to achieve success someday through the help of Kiva. She further said that she could be able to achieve success if she will continue working on towards the improvement of her business.

loans.use: additional capital for business improvement

loans.name: Erdenee

texts.en: Erdenee is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of his children attend a local secondary school while his wife helps him run his business. Erdenee owns and operates a successful household goods retail business in his town. He started his business in 2002 and attributes its success to his excellent accounting skills and he and his wife’s hard work. He hopes to one day move his business into his own store so that he can expand the number of products he sells. Erdenee is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug (~1400 USD) loan to purchase more household goods so that he can attract new customers.

loans.use: to purchase more household goods

loans.name: Mother Blessing Banjour Group

texts.en:
“Mother Blessing Banjour” is a group of five borrowers led by Musu F., a 34-year-old single mother of three children. Her children are aged 6 to 15 years old and their educational levels are 1st through 5th grade. Musu also cares for her parents and a few relatives. She is illiterate due to lack of financial support from her parents. Musu lives and works in Saye Town, Hotel Africa Road, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia.

Musu's business is charcoal. She buys charcoal wholesale from rural Liberia and brings it to Monrovia to sell to the residents of Saye Town. She has been running this business for ten years and hopes to build a shop in order to improve her business.

Musu's difficulty is the rainy season because, during this season it can be very hard to produce charcoal when it is wet. But she also gives her customers a good manner of approach in order to encourage them to always patronize her business.

Musu needs this loan in order to increase her capital so as to improve her business. She dreams of, in the future, building a house for herself and her family.

loans.use: To increase her capital so as to improve her business

loans.name: Nigmet

texts.en: Nigmet is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two youngest children in the Bayan-Ulgii province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son lives and works in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, while the younger children attend a local university in Bayan-Ulgii. Nigmet operates a coal delivery business in his town. Coal is an important energy source here in Mongolia because not everyone has access to, or can afford electricity. He began this business in 2006 after managing another transport business for 7 years. Nigmet delivers coal to contracted businesses and individuals all over town. During his three years in operation, he has gained a lot of business experience and a strong customer base. He says, “All I want is to be able to afford my children’s education and to buy a larger delivery truck in the future”.  Nigmet is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan in order to be able to buy a larger, more reliable delivery truck for his business.

loans.use: to buy a larger, more reliable delivery truck

loans.name: Enkhtsetseg

texts.en: D. Enkhtsetseg is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is a fireman, her oldest son is in high school, and her youngest son is in kindergarden. Enkhtsetseg operates a dairy product selling business in her town. She started her business in 2005, but after falling on hard times, closed the business in 2007. After learning from her experience, she re-opened the business in 2009. For the future, Enkhtsetseg hopes to grow her business to a stable operation. Her business is very important to her and she hopes her future earnings will improve her family's quality of life. She is requesting a 250,000 tugrug (~170 USD) loan to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.name: Erodelia

texts.en:
Erodelia is 41 years old and married to Conrado Sr.  They were blessed with five children: Rodalyn- 22 years old; Conrado Jr.- 21 years old, a security guard; Lanie-15 years old, 3rd year high school student; Eric- 8 years old, grade 2, in a primary level, and their youngest is John Carlo- 6 years old, already in preschool.  They are residing in San Francisco, Alicia, a rural and plain baranggay, their house is located between the rice fields and irrigation area.

She manages a duck-raising business and sometimes she also sells balut.  Her daily net income is PHP1,000.00. She decided to borrow a loan in KIVA amounting to PHP5,000.00 as business capital. She believes that "doing the best things comes the best gift that we always want".

loans.use: Additional capital in her Duck- Raising Business

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en: A. Otgonbayar is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. Her son and daughter both attend a local secondary school, and her husband is a taxi driver. They all live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Otgonbayar operates a small grocery trading business in her town. Currently, due to a lack of having an adequate selling location and place to store her products, she only operates her business during the summer. Otgonbayar started her grocery trading business in 1999 when she began growing and selling her own vegetables. For the future, she plans to rent a stall in a large market where she can sell year round. She is focused on growing her business, and says, "I want to buy 2 more hectares of land to grow more vegetables". She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase vegetables to sell this winter.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables to sell this winter

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en: Tsend-Ayush is 49 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Zavkhan province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her youngest daughter attends university and her husband is a taxi driver who helps Tsend-Ayush with her business in his spare time. Tsend-Ayush is a seamstress who specializes in traditional Mongolian clothes such as deels, or long coats. While people in larger towns and cities in Mongolia wear western style clothing, those in smaller provinces and sums wear more traditional Mongolian clothing. She has been operating her sewing business for 11 years and in that length of time she has gained a lot of business knowledge and experience. Tsend-Ayush dreams of one day owning in her own house where her family can live comfortably. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrug (~280 USD) loan in order to purchase deel fabric, materials and needles for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase deel fabric, materials and needles for her sewing business.

loans.name: Lailanie

texts.en:
Lailanie is 33 years old. She manages a a manicure and pedicure business in her village. She used to look around the village for customers just to earn a daily income for her family. She is married to Jaime, who is currently working abroad. They are blessed with two children: Jhon Lester, who is 9 years old (grade school), and the youngest is James, who is 3 years old.

To help her husband earn a living, Lalanie used her skills by offering manicures and pedicures. Her daily income enables her to provide for daily household expenses, especially the tuition fees and allowances of her eldest son. Lailanie is known for being friendly and a good neighbor. No wonder why she has lot of customers. She also does hair cutting and treatments. 

Lack of capital motivated her to seek for a loan request from Kiva lenders.  She is now asking to borrow a loan of PHP 5,000 that will be a big help in her business improvement. She hopes that this will be the beginning of her business growth. She also looks forward for having her own shop someday.

loans.use: Additional capital for her beauty service business

loans.name: Yanzaga

texts.en: N. Yanzaga is 34 years old and lives with his wife and three sons in Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest two sons attend a local secondary school and the youngest, 2 year-old, Batdorj, stays home with his mother. Yanzaga operates a wooden product making business in his town. He makes and sells a variety of furniture items to his customers. Yanzaga started his business in 2003. Since then, he has grown his business and is well established in the local business community. His earnings have enabled him to provide for his family and buy his own workshop. He says "My wish for the future is to save enough money for my children's education and one day build a house for my family." Yanzaga is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1050 USD) loan to purchase more wood for his wood products business.

loans.use: to purchase more wood for his wood products business

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a 47-year-old woman living in Consuelo, a small town near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. Rosalia has three children, but all have moved out of her home. Her youngest is 20 years old, and Rosalia is helping send her to university to study communications. Rosalia will use the loan to pay for a brand new bathroom that has been built behind her home.

Currently, Rosalia has a frituria (fried food stand) on the main street near her home. Here, she makes johnnycakes and other goodies for her neighbors and those working in or around the businesses on the street. She also sells coffee and tea to those on their way to and from work. Rosalia’s frituria is very popular, and the locals are always quick to grab a treat from her.

Rosalia lives in a neighborhood without many utilities. Living in a small town in the Dominican Republic can mean frequent power outages (if you have power to begin with), no plumbing, and insufficient shelter from the elements. Having a new bathroom has made her home more sanitary both for herself and for the preparation of food for the morning rush at her frituria. Having a bathroom means she has one less thing to worry about in her day to day activities. This is Rosalia’s seventh loan in five years with Esperanza, and her first housing development loan. Thank you for lending to Rosalia!

loans.use: Construction of new bathroom to make home more sanitary for food prep

loans.name: Abegail Joy

texts.en:
“Try and try until you succeed”, is the guiding principle of Abegail. She is 27 years old and gifted with five children. She is married and farming is their source of income. However, their income is not enough to support the immediate needs of the family and in providing the school allowance of their children. 

With her desire to help his husband in providing their needs, she wanted to borrow the amount of PHP4,000 for additional capital for her sari-sari store. She will use the loan to purchase more grocery items for her store that will increase her income.  She also plans to buy vegetables in the market and sells in their village.

loans.use: Additional capital to purchase more grocery items

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
“In God We Trust” is a group of five borrowers led by Siafa T., a 42-year-old married man. Siafa has three children aged 9 to 14 years old and their educational levels are 2nd through 6th grade. He is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support from his parents. Siafa lives and works in the Dualla community, north of Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. This is a very big commercial community and the majority of its inhabitants live on small and medium-sized businesses.

Siafa's business is the sale of fresh fish, meat and chicken. He buys his product wholesale from fishermen, poultrymen and butchers and sells to the local residents. He has been running this business for three years and hopes to become a business investor in the future.

Siafa's difficulty is the rainy season because, during this season, it can be very hard for customers to buy when it is wet. But he also gives his customers a good manner of approach and cleans his business premises in order to encourage them to always patronize his business.

Siafa needs this loan in order to increase his capital so as to improve his business. He dreams of building a house for himself and his family.

loans.use: To increase his capital so as to improve his business

loans.name: Adelina

texts.en:
Adelina is 56 years old and she is married to Victorino.  They help each other in managing their vulcanizing shop business. They have seven children, six of them are married and their youngest is Adela - 14 years old, a fourth year high school student.  They are living in Barangay Alicaocao, Cauyan City, a rural and plain area across a low bridge that overflows in times of heavy rains. 

They are earning a weekly gross income of PHP8, 000. They also buy and sell old car wheels that gives them additional income.  She is planning to ask for a loan amounting to PHP15, 000 from the KIVA lenders to further improve their business. She hopes to buy more items of car wheels to sell in their shop.

loans.use: Additional capital for their vulcanizing shop

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji M. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to purchase more yeast and firewood for brewing.  Keji is 28 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has one child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more yeast and firewood for brewing

loans.name: Lidia

texts.en:
Lidia is a 50-year-old mother of three children, ages 15, 17, and 20.  She currently lives with her common-law husband, and all three of her children are currently studying at university. For the past 15 years, Lidia has been tending to the land she inherited from her parents in an area of Cochabamba Department called Albra Rancho. Lidia is a very hard worker and has been through many tough times. A short while ago, her husband became psychologically ill and she has had to support her family on her own for over two years. She continues to work hard to make sure that her children do not miss out on any opportunities; Lidia wakes up at 4:30am to bring her livestock food and to begin milking them.  

With this loan from CIDRE, Lidia plans on purchasing soy husks for feeding her dairy cows. She believes this will help them increase her milk production, and in turn increase her earnings. Her dream is that her children all become professionals and have families of their own.

loans.use: The purchase of soy for livestock feed

loans.name: Iyom

texts.en:
Iyom L. is currently in the business of selling maize flour at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase beans, rice, etc., to sell. Iyom is 31 years old and is married with a husband who is a driver. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase beans and rice for resale

loans.name: Mae

texts.en:
Mae D. J., 22 years old, is a single young businesswoman. Hard work and patience is the guiding principle of Mae. At present, she would like to borrow PHP 5,000, which will serve as additional capital for her sari-sari (general store) business. Expansion of her store is what she wants to happen in order for her to support her family's needs.

Mae would be thankful if her loan request is approved. She is aiming for the improvement of her store and to have a better living.

loans.use: Additional capital to improve her store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Beatrice's Group

texts.en:
N. Beatrice is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 38 years old and married with eight children, all in secondary and primary schools. She also takes care of other siblings.

Beatrice is a business lady who has been involved in the sale of beverages and fruits in Najjembe for eight years. She is able to make 100,000/= as profits a week.

Beatrice is happy with her loans because she started her business with limited capital but the loans revived it. However, in some instances, there are few products for sale. She vies to become a supplier of farm produce as well as educating her children to the university level.

Beatrice needs a loan to be able to add more capital into her business to make more profits to pay school fees.

loans.use: To recapitalise her business by buying more beverages to sell

loans.name: Kujen

texts.en: Kujen B. is currently in the business of selling groundnut and simsim and is requesting a loan to purchase pulses and beans to sell.  Kujen is 33 years old and is Married with a husband that is a driver. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase pulses and beans to sell

loans.name: Allen's Group

texts.en: N. Allen is a hard working and determined lady. She is 31 years old and married with 5 children aged between 14 – 4 years as she takes care of her own siblings. She is involved in the sale of produce that she gets from the farmers in the villages and she sells from Namataba trading centre. Because of the use of her loans, she is able to inject in more money that help to make 100,000/= as profits a week out of the quality products that she buys. She vies to become a whole sale supplier of farm produce so that she could be able to make more money as well as educating her children to the University level. Allen needs a loan to help buy more produce for her business as well as complete payment of her children’s fees in time.

loans.use: Buying more produce for resale so as to make more profits.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 43 years old and she is married with seven children. She sells foodstuffs like bags of rice and beans and has been in this business for a long time.

Florence is determined to lift her business and family above poverty and hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She hopes for the loan of N140,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Khalim

texts.en: Khalim S. is currently in the business of selling cold drinks at the shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of soda and beer to sell.  Khalim is 26 years old and is Married with a husband that is a police man. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school and provide them with scholarstic materials  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase more crates of soda and beer to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To pay for new walls and a ceiling in her home and business

loans.name: Mayimuna's Group

texts.en: N. Mayimuna is a 32 year old lady and the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a widow with 6 children of her own as she takes care of her other step children. Mayimuna is a shop keeper in Kasangalabi and since this is her new business from farming, she is able to make 40,000/= as profits a week.  Her major business challenge is the lack of enough capital to boost her business since she is a good person in as far as taking care of her customers is concerned. Mayimuna needs a loan to help restock her shop with more products so as to make more profits out of it.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more goods for increased profits.

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni E. is currently in the business of baking and selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase baking flour. Poni is 39 years old and married to a policeman. She has one child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase baking flour

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
“Work hard and commitment to God is the weapon in achieving success in life” said Eva A.. Eva is 40 years old and she is married to Elson.  They are thankful because they were blessed with five children: Sanny Boy-20 years old, high school graduate; Jackilyn-16 years old, 4th year high school; Mark-12 years old;Jay-R - three years old and the youngest is Mar-one year old. Her family lives in the village of Rizal West, San Isidro. The couple are striving hard to meet the needs of their family.  

Eva is a hog raiser while her husband is a busy cultivating their rice fields and same time repairing some houses in their village to have additional source of income. The  couple would like to generate bigger capital for their growing needs.  But their income to their hog raising business is not enough so Eva is borrowing  a loan of PHP4 000 to the KIVA lenders to further improve her business and so with their way of living.  The loan will be of great help in purchasing supply of feeds for her hogs.  She is hoping that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: Additional capital for hog raising business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shola

texts.en: Shola is 40 years old and she is married with 4 children.She sells detergent in retail to her customers in Lagos state, Nigeria. She started this business in the year 2000. She uses her experience in the business to atrract and retain her customers.She hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more detergent to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more detergent to sell

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said A. is 30 years old and a married father of two children. His wife, Susan Okora, is 26 years old and is a business lady. Said operates a store in Shanzu, Mombasa, where he sells clothes and shoes. His business is eight years old and is a success.

Said is accessing his first loan from KADET and he plans to use it to purchase more shoes and clothes for his store. Currently, Said's major customers are residents of the beach town of Shanzu. Said hopes to expand his business by opening a chain of stores in the future and to diversify his source of income by venturing into the car-rental market.  

About KADET: 

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the micro-finance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase his stock in clothes and shoes

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice K. is the leader of her group in Lugazi. She is a hardworking and determined lady who has had a retail shop in the Samuuka trading center for 10 years. Before the retail shop, Alice was a farmer and because her farm produce was mostly affected by seasonal changes and fluctuating prices, she opened up a shop from which she makes 60,000 Ugandan shillings as a weekly profit. 

She is grateful for her loans since they help increase her capital and hence, her profitability. Alice has a dream of becoming a wholesale supplier of shop products so that she could be able to educate her children to the last level. She is a mother of six children ranging in age from 3 to 17 years and she takes care of other orphans. 

Alice needs a loan to help add more capital into her business since this ensures a steady running of the business and payment of school fees on time.

loans.use: Restocking her retail shop with more products for increased productivity

loans.name: Edna

texts.en: Edna is married with a child and she is 40 years old.She is a happy and hard working woman.She sells clothes and shoes of various colours and sizes.She is happy with this business because she has lots of customers that patronizes her business.she hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Regina

texts.en: Regina is 39 years old, married, and is blessed with six children. Her supermarket business is located in Junction in Eldoret Town. Regina was introduced to KADET by another client. With the loan she is expecting from KADET she intends to add more stock which includes sugar, bar soap, rice and oil. Her dreams are to improve the business and also improve the family’s living standards. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more goods to her store

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en: N. Rose is 25 years old and married with 4 children aged 12 – 3 years as she takes care of her siblings. She is a friendly and determined lady with a business of selling agricultural produce from Namataba trading centre for 3 years. This is her first business ever and she hopes for it to grow more in future by becoming a whole sale supplier. In a week, Rose is able to make 50,000/= as profits and these help to reinvest in her business as well as educating her children. She needs a loan to help add more capital in her business for the steady supply of products to her customers.

loans.use: Buying more farm produce for her business.

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel trabaja en la confección de mantas y polleras tiene una tienda en alquiler; tiene 4 hijos, si bien viven en casa propia la misma es de adobe y ladrillo ubicada en la zona Nueva Jerusalén Río Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto.
El esposo trabaja como transportista inter-departamental.

El crédito lo destinará para la compra de materia prima (tela), de esa forma podrá satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado.
 
Es el quinto crédito con IMPRO, sus créditos anteriores fueron cancelados puntualmente, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por Isabel.

loans.use: compra de telas para su negocio de confección de mantas y polleras.

loans.name: Hellen Cherop

texts.en:
Hellen is 24 years old .Her business is located in Eldoret Town.

She was introduced to KADET by other clients.

With the loan Hellen is taking from from KADET she intends to add more spare parts for her spare part shop and also add more detergents.Her dreams are to better her business to serve other people and to put more efforts in her business so as to improve her living standards.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more spare parts and other detegents which includes oil.

loans.name: Bukky

texts.en: Bukky is 34 years old and married with 2 children.  She buys crates of soft drinks to retail to her customers. She hopes to receive a loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more supplies of drinks to resell. She is indeed grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of soft drinks to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: acheter des engrais et payer du labour

loans.name: Sophia's Group

texts.en: Sophia K. leads a loan group located in the town of Lugazi. She is 26 years old, married, has one child of her own and also takes care of her siblings. For the last two years, she has made a living selling fish, and is grateful that she has been able to earn enough to enjoy a decent standard of living. Sophia has applied for and received previous loans which have helped her keep her business going and even expand it by buying quality products. She will continue to work hard because she would like to earn enough money to build her own home and send her child and her siblings to school through the university level. Sophia has applied for a new loan to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Olufunke

texts.en: Olufunke is 44 years old and married with 2 children. She sells tubers of yam to make a living within her community in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more tubers of yam to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristine is managing a general store for ten years.  She is 61 years old and still very diligent in doing her business.  She is married and blessed with 12 children and they all have their own families. Her business is of big help in providing the needs of their family. 

Cristina is praying for good health condition.  Her income is not enough to support the medicine of his husband who is ill. Through her business income, she can provide the medicines of his husband.  She is hoping that the KIVA lenders will grant her loan request of PHP13,000.  She will use the loan to buy more stocks for her store.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Chinyere

texts.en: Chinyere is 40 years old, married and has one child. She makes a living selling food such as noodles, sugar and milk. She has applied for this loan to buy more items to sell, and wants to extend her thanks to all Kiva lenders for making this assistance possible.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: acheter du riz et des tomates pour son restaurant

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is engaged in hog raising business in the village of Addalam Jones, Isabela. She is married to Antonio Jr. who is a farmer. She would like to maintain her hog raising business by providing enough supply of feeds for her hogs.  For this, she is borrowing PHP4,000 as additional capital to pursue her plans. 

Rosie and Antonio Jr. have two children who are still studying. The eldest is John Anthony-14 years old and Rex-13 years old. Rosie hopes that her two children could finish their schooling. The couple hopes for the support of the KIVA lenders to their business

loans.use: Additional capital for business maintenance

loans.name: Marget

texts.en: Marget is 50 years old and married with 6 children.  She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells books and stationary. Marget hopes for the loan amount of N150, 000 to purchase more books and stationary to sell. she says thanks to all kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more books and stationary to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: New addition to home/business

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito is 51 years old and living in the village of Villa Corazon, Mallig, Isabela. She and her husband are working as farmers and also engaged in furniture making business.  They are blessed with four children and all of them were able to graduate from college. She has been in the business for 24 years and she now would like to expand in selling cassava cake in their village for additional income.

She needs to have additional income because she is providing her children with their school allowance.  With her need of business capital, she is now asking to borrow for a loan of PHP5,000 to pursue her plan of starting a new business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela is 45 years old and has six children. She earns a living by selling rechargeable phone cards, and has applied for this loan to buy more cards to sell. She extends heartfelt thanks to all Kiva lenders for making it possible for her to do this.

loans.use: To buy more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Teofila

texts.es:
La señora Teofila C. vive en alquiler con su hija en la calle inca roca de la zona de Tacagua de la ciudad de La Paz; se dedica a la elaboración de empanadas fritas en aceite, las cuales las vende al lado del cine todos los días a partir de las 4:00 de la tarde; con esta actividad ella se mantiene desde hace mucho tiempo y el crédito que solicita es para comprar insumos (harina, queso, levadura) por cantidad y así obtener costos menores y por ende mayor ganancia.

Es cliente de Impro Desde el año 2008 y paga muy puntualmente, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Teofila C. lives in a rented home with her daughter in Inca Roca street in the Tacagua zone in La Paz. She makes empanadas fried in oil which she sells beside a cinema every day from 4 o'clock in the afternoon, and she has lived off this small business for a long time. With this loan she will purchase supplies (flour, cheese, yeast) in bulk whose lower cost will result in better earnings for her. Toefila has been a client of Impro since 2008 and pays very punctually, which is why she has been granted a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of flour, cheese, oil and yeast for her fried empanada business

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
El señor Jorge V. vive con sus hijos en casa propia en la calle Alberto Ostria de la zona de tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz; percibe una renta de jubilación con la cual se mantiene ya que sus hijos son mayores. El crédito que solicita es para pagar los costos de inscripción y matrícula  de su nieto en la Universidad y darle una profesión para que pueda defenderse en la vida ya que los padres de el niño no cuentan con suficientes ingresos.

Es cliente de Impro desde al año 2006 y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Jorge V. lives with his adult children in his own house, located on Alberto Ostria street in the Tembladerani neighborhood of La Paz. He receives a pension which provides him with adequate support, since his children are already grown. The loan Jorge is requesting will go to pay the registration fees and tuition for his grandson at the University, in order to give the young man a profession that will allow him to make his own way in life, since his parents do not have sufficient income. Jorge has been a client of Impro since 2006, and he has an excellent payment history, allowing him to qualify for new credit.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Registration fees and tuition for his grandson at the University

loans.name: Seun

texts.en: Seun is 32 years old, married and has two children. She makes a living selling textbooks, and has applied for this loan to buy more items to sell to her customers. She extends thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more textbooks to sell

loans.name: Omolabaka

texts.en:
Omolabake is 47 years old and she is married with 5 children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria where she sells bags of charcoal in wholesale and retail. 
Omolabake hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To stock rice and to buy and sell oil, canned goods, etc.

loans.name: Omotayo

texts.en: Omotayo is 30 years old, married and has two children. She makes a living selling bags of charcoal to both wholesale and retail customers. Omotayo has applied for a loan to buy more bags of  charcoal to sell. She extends sincere thanks to all Kiva lenders for making it possible for her to do this.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
Shirley A. is now 33 years old, happy and contented with her partner in life Moises A. who is now 36 years old. They have five children May Ann 17 years old, Ana Marie 15 years old, Caren 14 years old, Keyzee 8 years old and Elizabeth 6 years old. As of now they’re all studying, so they spend more money for the school expenses of her children. She and her husband work hard for them to earn enough income for their everyday expenses in the house and expenses of her children in school.

Aside from her sewing different kinds of dress, they have a fishing business that becomes their main source of income. This business runs for 2 years now and they really want to continue it because it gives them more income. It suits their place because their near the sea maybe this is one reason why it give them income. Her husband manages it with her help of course. She will use the loan that she received from Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) to buy things for this business like different kinds of fishnet and accessories for it.

Shirley hopes that someday her children will finish their studies because this is the reason why they work hard for them to have a good education. And one hopes of Shirley is to make her business stable for them to alleviate from poverty.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her fishing business

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena A. is now 31 years old and happily married to the father of her 4 children Angelo 14 years old, Antonette 13 years old, Austin John 4 years old and Alwyun 2 years old, Anselmo who is now 32 years old. As of now all of their children are all studying, so more expenses from them. Her husband manages their fishing business of course with her help. They start this last 2 years and as of now it is still running. They came up to this business because before her husband work as a fisherman and it gives them not enough income for their big expenses.

When she joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) she used the loan that she received to finance this business and now she also want to use this again to buy necessary things needed in their business like different kind of fishnet and different accessories for it. These things will help their business to earn more income for them.

Rowena dream of having a bigger boat that help their business to be more productive, in order for them to improve their status in life, and of course she really hopes that someday all her children will finish their studies.

loans.use: To finance her fishing business

loans.name: Chidima

texts.en: Chidima is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She sells text books. Chidima hopes to receive a loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more supplies of text books to sell. Chidima says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies of text books to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase generic medicines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Will be use for her pig raising business, also for her fishing business

loans.name: Yawa Eugénie

texts.fr: Cette femme est mariée et est mère de 03 enfants ; son mari est Directeur d’école. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente d’une bouillie dénommée « akassa », très appréciée de la population. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 1996, et cette activité lui permet d’apporter sa part financière dans la vie du foyer ; elle vend le plus souvent les matins et a une clientèle assez disparate, composée essentiellement des élèves, des  gens de petits métiers et bien d’autres catégories socio professionnelles. Elle a une expérience bien solide dans le domaine puisqu’elle sait bien accueillir sa clientèle. Actuellement elle a besoin de s’approvisionner en maïs ; c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 03 sacs de maïs, 02 sacs de sucres et un panier d’arachide. Elle exerce son activité dans le quartier d’Avédji à Lomé
texts.en:
Madame N. is married and has three children. Her husband is a school principal. To earn a living, she sells a much-appreciated porridge known as "akassa". Madame N. started this business in 1996 and it allows her to contribute to the household expenses. She usually sells the porridge in the morning, to an assorted clientele made up mostly of school children, traders and people from many other socio-professional groups. Madame N. has a great deal of experience in her field and knows exactly how to attract customers. She currently needs to stock up on corn, so she is requesting a loan from Kiva Field Partner, WAGES, to buy three sacks of corn, two sacks of sugar and a basket of peanuts. She conducts her business activity in the Avédji neighborhood in Lomé.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of corn and sugar, and a basket of peanuts

loans.name: Dionisia

texts.en:
Life for the family of Dionisia C. is not easy. At her age which is 66 she really work hard to support their daily needs. She is already a widowed, her son Wilfredo help her improve their lives. He work as a factory worker to earn income for her family and her mother. But his salary from his more is not enough for their daily expenses and other expenses, so her mother help him earning incomes for them though her business which is making of bamboo basket.

Dionisia always use the loan that she received from Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) in her business like today she will use her loan in buying things needed by her business so that her business continue to run and continue to help to lessen their burden in their expenses.

Dionisia’s dream is to make her business become successful so that she can give her son as well as the family of her son a better life and also to give others opportunity to have a job.

loans.use: For additional capital in her making of bamboo basket business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: effectuer le labour et acheter des fertilisants.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 40 years old and a widow with 5 children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria where she sells clothing. She has been in this business for long, Rita hopes to receive a loan in the amount of N140, 000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou S. est âgé  de 35 ans, sans enfant, il vit avec sa femme dans un foyer monogame  dans la  quartier Hèrèmakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Suite à la pauvreté de ses parents, il décida d’abandonner l’école pour entreprendre des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son oncle qui lui appris  le commerce d’articles divers de boutique.  Avec une expérience de 6 ans, Monsieur Seydou S. maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité.
Pour obtenir un fonds de roulement considérable, il décida de collaborer  avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte acheter  avec ce prêt une importante quantité d’articles divers pour sa boutique.  
Il ’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes et effectue sa vente, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée de toute la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 49 500 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir sa boutique et payer les intérêts du prêt.

loans.use: Achat d’articles divers  de  boutique.

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda M. is a 54 year-old widow who has 6 children who were left fatherless at a very young age when their father died late last year. Her oldest son, Jimmy is just 19 years old and has settled down with his own family, but the rest of Gilda's children are still going to school. Jimmy helps his mother run their small restaurant in Isabela, Negros Occidental. Gilda hopes that all of her younger children will be able to finish their college education so that they could earn good incomes and provide for their own families.

The death of her husband left Gilda alone to raise her family, but she faced this trial with courage and conviction because her love and concern for her children transcended any difficulty that she experienced. She doubled her efforts knowing that she was the only one left who could provide for the family.

Even with her recent loss, Gilda was not fazed by the trials that have come to her at that time. She knew that she could sustain her family if she held on and used her skills and knowledge in running a food business. This is not surprising because she's been doing it for quite a long time. She was already engaged in food vending long before she married her husband, and continued with it during her married life, becoming her husband's helpmate in supporting their large family. 

She also trained her children while they were young and now they are also able to lend a hand in running the business when they had no school work. In 2006, Gilda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon so that she could expand her business. As she paid off each loan on time and performing well as a member, Gilda gained access to larger loans which she fully made use of by expanding her operations even further. It now earns her a monthly net income of PHP 7,500.


Her previous loan of Php 13,000 was used as additional capital for her business, and she was able to repay her loan on time without any delays. For her 7th cycle loan, she intends to borrow the same amount to be used as additional capital for her business and whatever income from it will be used for the education of her children and for her family needs.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her Food Vending and Restaurant Business

loans.name: Kwassi Mawutodji

texts.fr: Cette jeune fille vend des cartes de recharges dans une baraque située au bord d’une route internationale, dans le quartier d’Adidogomé à Lomé. Elle a débuté ce commerce depuis 2005 ; cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge et de subvenir à la plupart de ses besoins. Elle aime son commerce et accueille bien ses clients, ce qui fait qu’il y a des gens qui préfèrent toujours acheter des cartes chez elle. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a pas non plus aucun enfant à sa charge. Actuellement elle a besoin de renouveler son stock en baisse ; c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des cartes de recharge cellulaires Togocel et Illico. Elle n’a aucune inquiétude pour rembourser son prêt à temps.

loans.use: Achat de cartes de recharges cellulaires

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Idrissa Dembélé est âgé de 29 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants et sa femme  dans la  quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école moderne, très vite il commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment l’achat et la vente des  chaussures, pendant plus de 8 ans, au marché de Bougouni et cela  sans succès. C’est ainsi qu’il décida d’apprendre la vente d’articles divers de  boutique auprès de son beau-frère.  Il exerce cette activité il y a environ 5 années  et la maitrise parfaitement de nos jours.
Pour le renforcement de son commerce, il décida de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son  premier prêt  individuel pour acheter des articles divers pour sa boutique.  
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni auprès des grossistes et revend en détail au comptant et à crédit à  une   clientèle  composée de toute la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA.qui servira à  agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Idrissa Dembélé is 29 years old and lives with his two children and wife in the Torakabougou district of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended a modern school, he quickly began earning an income, notably through commerce in shoes eight years ago at the Bougouni market. But this was unsuccessful. And so he decided to learn about selling various store items with his brother-in-law. He has been in this business for five years and has now mastered it. To bolster his business, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan, which he will use to buy various goods for his shop. He stocks up in Bougouni from wholesale merchants and sells the goods retail, cash or credit accepted. His customers are made up of the entire local population. With this loan, he plans on realizing a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA that will serve to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods for his store

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Souleymane S. est marié, âgé de 30 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le  quartier Torakabougou de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques telles les travaux journaliers auprès des maçons, les travaux champêtres et le berger. 
Vu l’âge avançant, il songe  à avoir une activité stable et pérenne. Ainsi il décida de mener l’activité d’achat et de  vente d’articles divers de  boutique,  qu’il appris auprès de son grand frère. Avec une expérience de 5 ans, Monsieur Souleymane S. maîtrise bien son activité qu’il pilote allègrement.
Après avoir correctement remboursé le prêt précédent, il est à son deuxième prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter d’importantes  articles divers pour sa boutique afin d’attirer, de satisfaire et de maintenir la clientèle. 
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) et vend en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle  composée de toute la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Souleymane S. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 87000 FCFA. 
Avec ce bénéfice il envisage agrandir sa boutique et acheter une maison.
texts.en:
Mr. Souleymane S. is 30 years old, married and the father of 2 children. He lives with his wife and children in theTorakabougou neighborhood of Bougouni town (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having been unschooled, he began very quickly economic activities such as daily masonry work, farm work and herdsman. Given his advancing age, he thinks of having a stable and sustainable business. So, he decided to run the business of buying and selling of various store items that he learned from his elder brother. With a five-year experience, Mr. Souleymane S. controls well his business that he operates cheerfully. After having repaid correctly the previous loan, he is on his second individual loan which he intends to use to buy various important items for his store in order to attract, please and maintain customers. He gets his supplies in Bamako ( the capital of the Republic of Mali) and retails cash down and on credit to his customers comprised of all the local people. With this loan, Mr. Souleymane S. intends to make a monthly profit of 87000FCFA. With this profit, he plans to expand his store and buy a house.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various store items

loans.name: Bendia Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Bendia sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies, avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent dans le village Noumouwèrè, dans la préfecture de Ségou (4ème  Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Village des forgerons comme son nom l’indique, elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et appartiennent à une association  traditionnelle de femme. Ce groupe de femmes vend des mortiers, des louches, des pilons, et des calebasses décorés. 
Dans le but d’associer autres activités artisanales à celles qu’elles mènent, elles ont  adhéré au programme crédit de  Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 7ème cycle, après six prêts solidaires tous correctement remboursés.
Ce  nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 15 colis de calebasses (chaque colis contient 20 à 30 calebasses) et 20 mortiers. Les calebasses et les mortiers achetés sont limés et gravés  de dessins avant d’être mis au marché. Elles se ravitaillent en calebasses dans les foires de Tonan, Cinzana, au grand marché de Ségou et en mortiers dans le village de Togo avec les hommes. Les produits sont revendus au comptant au bord du goudron à côté de la grande mosquée et en ambulant dans les quartiers de Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et acheter les condiments au quotidien. 
Elles ont pour ambition l’installation d’un moulin dans le village afin d’avoir plus de temps pour leurs activités génératrices de revenus et l’achat du matériel de travail qu’on appelle soufflet.

loans.use: Achat de calebasses et de mortiers.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette dame vend dans le marché de Bè à Lomé des mèches, des sacs pour dame et des habits de petites filles. Grâce à ce commerce, elle arrive à subvenir à ses besoins de base ; elle a débuté cette activité depuis 2004. Elle n’est pas mariée et n’a pas non plus aucun enfant à sa charge. Elle a loué dans le marché un petit espace qui lui permet de vendre ses articles. Elle est connue de nombreuses personnes car accueillant bien sa clientèle. Actuellement elle est presque en rupture de stock pour les tissages et les habits d’enfants. Pour cela, elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 250 mèches Outré, 80 tissages et 200 pièces d’habits pour petites filles. Elle pense que ce prêt apportera un grand changement dans son commerce.
texts.en:
In the market of Bè à Lomé, this woman sells hair extensions, bags for women and clothes for little girls. Thanks to this business, she is able to provide for her basic needs. She started this business in 2004. She is not married and does not have any children in her care. She rents a small space in the market, where she can sell her wares. She is well-known by numerous people for welcoming her clientele. Currently, she is almost out of her stock of hair extensions and children's clothes. In order to re-stock, she is requesting a loan from the micro-finance organization WAGES in order to purchase 250 Outré brand hair extensions, 80 sets of weaves and 200 sets of clothes for little girls. She thinks that this loan will give her the opportunity to make big changes in her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions, weaves and clothes for little girls

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de cinq femmes toutes  mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies, avec en moyenne  42 ans, 4 enfants et habitant dans le même village Noumouwèrè, relevant de la  préfecture de Ségou (4ème  Région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes forgerons de la contrée. 
Ce groupe de femmes s’est spécialisé dans la vente d’articles artisanaux.
Dans le souci d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles  sont à leur 7ème cycle après avoir correctement remboursé les six précédents prêts.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 colis de calebasses (chaque colis contient 20 à 30 calebasses). Les calebasses achetées sont limées et gravées  de dessins avant d’être mises au marché. En plus de l’artisanat, certaines du groupe  vendent de la pâte d’arachide à domicile et au grand marché de Ségou.  
Elles se ravitaillent en calebasses dans les foires de Tonan, Cinzana, Konodimini et au grand marché de Ségou.  Les produits sont revendus au comptant au bord du goudron à proximité de la grande mosquée et en ambulant à travers la ville de Ségou à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 21.500FCFA qui sera utilisé pour prendre en charge les condiments, les frais de santé et d’habillements des enfants. 
Elles ont pour ambition l’installation d’un moulin dans le village afin qu’elles aient plus de temps pour leurs activités génératrices de revenu et l’achat d’une charrette et un âne pour leur transport dans les foires.

loans.use: Achat de calebasses.

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar es un joven soltero de 28 años, muy responsable y algo tímido, actualmente vive en una casa alquilada. Hace 8 meses inició su negocio de venta de abarrotes en un espacio de su vivienda, la cual está muy cerca de una escuela de su localidad, por lo que desde que empezaron las clases sus ventas de golosinas han aumentando. Por tal motivo ha empezado a preparar otros bocadillos y postres como: gelatinas, papas rellenas y chupetes, los cuales ofrece durante el tiempo de recreo de los estudiantes de la escuela vecina. De esta forma, Edgar puede obtener el dinero necesario para pagar el alquiler de la casa y sus gastos personales. Por eso se siente muy contento con su negocio, ya que tener una tienda era uno de sus anhelos desde años atrás y ahora que ya lo tiene lo piensa conservar y ahorrar lo suficiente para comprarse un terreno y construir su propia casa. 
Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, él se lleva muy bien con todos los integrantes de su banco comunal y asiste a todas las reuniones de su grupo. El dinero que ahora solicita la utilizará en la compra de bebidas gasificadas de diversas marcas y sabores.
texts.en:
Edgar is a single young man who is 28 years old. He is very responsible and a bit shy. He currently lives in a rented house. Eight months ago, he started a grocery business in his home which is very close to a local school. Since classes have started up again, his sales of candies have grown. For this reason, he has started preparing other snacks and desserts such as jello, stuffed potatoes and lollipops which he sells during the school's recess. In this way, Edgar can earn the money he needs to pay his rent and personal expenses. This makes him very happy with his business and it was one of his dreams to have his own store. Now that he has one, he would like to save up to buy land and build his own home. This is his second loan with MFP. He gets along very well with the other members of his village bank and attends all of the group meetings. He will use the loan to buy different brands and flavors of sodas.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Herminia

texts.es:
Herminia tiene 29 años, vive con su pareja y padre de sus 3 hijos en una casa alquilada.
